title: 109_hr3492
content: The Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005 prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from using adverse information to change interest rates on consumer credit accounts. The issuer must clearly inform the consumer about this limitation in any required disclosures or statements. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and a percentage of the outstanding balance. The amendment to the Truth in Lending Act requires clear and conspicuous repayment information on credit card balances, including the minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance. It also mandates disclosing the number of months it would take to pay off the balance by making only minimum payments with no further advances. The amendment to the Truth in Lending Act mandates clear disclosure of repayment information on credit card balances, including minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance. It also requires stating the number of months needed to pay off the balance by making only minimum payments with no further credit advances. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest for disclosures. The creditor must apply the annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the disclosure date, considering different rates for various outstanding balance portions, regardless of whether they are fixed or variable rates. When disclosing a temporary or introductory rate that will change based on an index or formula, the creditor must apply the annual percentage rate in effect on the disclosure date for determining the balance. The disclosure must include the annual percentage rate based on an index, formula, or contractual provision in effect on the disclosure date for determining the balance during the introductory period. The disclosure must include the annual percentage rate based on an index, formula, or contractual provision in effect on the disclosure date for determining the balance during the introductory period. The determination for the remainder of the amortization period will be made as of the disclosure date. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. The Truth in Lending Act now mandates advance notice of any interest rate or fee increases on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. Increases in annual percentage rates must be communicated to the obligor at least 30 or 60 days before the billing cycle begins, depending on the reason for the rate change. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of interest rate or fee increases on credit card accounts. Changes in annual percentage rates must be communicated to the obligor at least 30 or 60 days before the billing cycle begins, depending on the reason for the rate change. The obligor must receive specific notice of any increase in the annual percentage rate, and the new rate may apply to any outstanding balance as of the date of the notice. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of interest rate or fee increases on credit card accounts. No fees can be imposed on a credit card account before the obligor receives a specific notice of the fee imposition, which must be sent within a 30-day period. The notice requirements for fee imposition on credit card accounts mandate separate mailing or emailing of notices to the obligor without any advertising. The notice must include an explanation of how, when, and why a fee will be imposed, along with options for the obligor to address it. The notice must include an explanation of how, when, and why a fee will be imposed, and the options available to the obligor to address it.
